choices.F: It can get input from SQL Scripts in flat files.
choices.A: It can get input from the Automatic Workload Repository (AWR).
choices.B: It can run while a maintenance window is open.
choices.C: It can recommend creation of SQL plan baselines.
choices.E: It prevents regression of SQL statement performance.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about the SQL Tuning Advisor? (Choose three.)

discussion.content: Following the link I think ACE should be the correct answers

comments.content:
B not C
The SQL Tuning Advisor analyzes one or more SQL statements one at a time. It examines
statistics, SQL profiles, indexes, materialized views, and restructured SQL. The SQL Tuning
Advisor can be run manually at any time, but it is run during every maintenance window
against the recent high-load SQL statements.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about Oracle checkpoint processing? (Choose three.)

choices.E: Thread checkpoints ensure that all dirty buffers are written to data files during a normal shutdown
choices.C: It reduces the recovery time from instance failures
choices.D: Incremental checkpoints write some dirty buffers to the datafiles and unwritten redo to the online redo logs.
choices.A: Frequent thread checkpoints can degrade database performance
choices.B: Database Writer (DBWn) processes write checkpoint information to datafile headers and the control file

questions.question_text:
You want a job that performs a bulk insert as soon as the loader file arrives on the local file system.
Which two would you do to accomplish this? (Choose two.)

comments.content: I think there will be lack of something to trigger the event start.

choices.C: Create a light weight job for bulk insert
choices.E: Create a job chain with a step for bulk insert
choices.D: Create an event-based job for bulk insert

choices.A: A database destination must exist or be created for the remote database
choices.D: A credential is optional for a remote database job
choices.G: A destination is optional for a remote database job because DB links can be used instead
choices.E: A credential must be created to define the remote user
choices.C: Remote database jobs always run as the same user who submits the job on the local database
choices.F: A database destination group must exist or be created for a job to run on multiple remote databases
choices.B: It must run as a user that is defined on the remote database

questions.question_text: Which four are true about creating and running a remote database scheduler jobs? (Choose four.)

discussion.content:
ABDF is correct:
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMIN/schedover.htm#ADMIN033

A. By not specifying a destination attribute, in which case the job runs locally.
B. Remote database jobs must run as a user that is valid on the target database
D. You can specify a job credential by specifying a named credential object or by allowing the credential attribute of the job to remain NULL. 
F. You can also create a destination group, which consists of a list of destinations, and reference this destination group when creating a job. In this case, the job runs on all destinations in the group.

Selected Answer: ABDF
Answer is ABDF

Selected Answer: ABDF
You do not have to create a credential, but you need to prefix the destination with credential. Therefor e) is not correct.

Should be ABEF. 
Here is a remote database.
D: By allowing the credential attribute of the job to remain NULL, in which case a local database job runs as the job owner. (See Table 28-1.) The job owner is the schema in which the job was created.

comments.content:
For D:In the docs,the description of paramter destination_name,which is using in DBMS_SCHEDULER.CREATE_JOB, memtions that "If the credential_name argument of CREATE_JOB is NULL, each destination must be preceded by a credential, in the following format:credential.destination.The credential must already exist. If the credential_name argument is provided, then it serves as the default credential for every destination that is not preceded by a credential."
ref https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ARPLS/d_sched.htm#ARPLS72300

For G:In the docs, it says that "You define where a job runs by specifying a one or more destinations. Destinations are also Scheduler objects and are described later in this section. If you do not specify a destination, it is assumed that the job runs on the local database."
ref https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMIN/schedover.htm#ADMIN-GUID-6BADB539-62DB-468D-9685-A855FC133902
Database link is not mentioned in the documentation.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about SQL*Loader Express Mode in an Oracle 12c database? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
Answer is BC

Selected Answer: BC
Express mode is not the same as direct load, it is just a way of executing sql*loader in a simple way.

choices.D: It loads data more efficiently than conventional SQL*Loader
choices.B: No data file needs to be specified
choices.C: It can load data in parallel
choices.A: It loads data faster than conventional SQL*Loader
choices.E: It requires Enterprise Manager Express to be configured
